title: ZERO
text: zero  zero, a musician, artist and psychology graduate currently experiencing houselessness in hobart, articulates a profound philosophy on community, connection, and the distinction between house and home. living between tents, shelters, and hostels for two years, he advocates for third spaces where people can simply exist without economic pressure, creating organic community bonds through art, music, and free exchange. "house, four walls home, that feeling of love, and you can have that sense of home with you if you have community wherever you are, and if you have connection to the earth and to yourself, that's home."

title: Aaron Stapleton
text: aaron stapleton aaron stapleton, 42, experienced a dramatic life reversal from managing a company to homelessness following personal losses, relationship breakdown, and incarceration. now staying at vinny's shelter and utilizing their laundry services, aaron is focused on rebuilding his life while maintaining his dignity and independence. homelessness, you never think it's gonna happen to you 'cause it could any day.

title: Wayne Tait
text: wayne tait wayne tate, a newcastle resident experiencing homelessness, demonstrates remarkable resilience and dignity through his daily routines. utilizing orange sky's laundry services to maintain clean clothes, wayne emphasizes how this practical support not only helps him navigate public spaces without stigma but also maintains his self-confidence during challenging life circumstances. "if it wasn't for the orange sky service, i wouldn't have the clean clothes to whack on every day."

title: Sarah Mayers
text: sarah mayers sarah jessica meyers has navigated a challenging journey from troubled youth in tasmania's welfare and justice systems to pursuing education and working in youth services. despite experiencing addiction, homelessness, and incarceration, she earned her youth work certification and briefly worked for the council, maintaining a commitment to self-improvement and helping others avoid similar struggles. i think everyone has different problems. we all come from different walks of life, and sometimes you've just gotta be there for yourself instead of looking for outside validation.

title: AJ Bailey
text: aj bailey aj bailey transitioned from experiencing homelessness as a street person at st. pat's to becoming a team leader at orange sky, where he conducts shifts in perth and gosnells. his lived experience of homelessness provides him with unique insights into the challenges faced by those accessing orange sky's laundry and shower services. "i love giving it back to the community. i feel good inside because i know what it's like because i've been on the street myself."

title: Graham
text: graham graham is a service user at orange sky in newcastle who values the service not only for practical laundry assistance when his washing machine malfunctions but primarily for the social connections and community he experiences there. having previously volunteered with seoul for six years, graham maintains a positive outlook while acknowledging the challenges faced by those experiencing homelessness. "i like the people that work here. i know, it's not a chore... it's more part of my social life."

title: Felicity Davis-Smith
text: felicity davis-smith felicity davis-smith, a binary transgender woman currently experiencing homelessness in hobart, navigates complex intersections of gender identity, housing insecurity, and community acceptance. despite facing discrimination in her housing search, she maintains her dignity and sense of self while finding unexpected community support at local shelters and services like orange sky. "it's awesome having someone to have a chat. it's cool to be able to do that, especially when you're going through a time that's probably not the greatest in your life."

title: Phil Barton
text: phil barton phillip, a humble yet impactful figure in kalgoorlie, operates orange sky's mobile laundry service with remarkable dedication. rising early each morning, he provides clean clothes and dignity to those experiencing hardship, creating a trusted space where community members find both practical support and meaningful human connection. "it's just laundry, but it's not just laundry. it's... it's giving people back a bit of themselves."
